1.  The letter was written in good language and used a stamp as a sign of an official letter.

2.  The letter came from Sulaiman, as a king and a prophet.

3.  The letter began with *Bismillahir Rahmanir Rahim*.

According to a narration, Sulaiman's letter was the first letter to begin with the basmalah. The way of making letters as done by Prophet Sulaiman is a good way to be emulated by every Muslim when making letters.

There are several things that happened thanks to the special qualities of Sulaiman's letter, including:

1.  The letter was delivered by the hud-hud bird in a short time to the Queen of Sheba.

2.  The ability of the hud-hud bird to receive messages and capture conversations in the negotiations between the Queen of Sheba and her dignitaries.

3.  The letter could also be understood and comprehended by the people of Sheba.

4.  The envoys of the leaders of the people of Sheba could express their opinions freely. There was nothing preventing them from expressing their respective opinions. Thus, the result of the deliberation was a result that was in accordance with the thoughts and opinions of the people of Sheba.
text.31: This verse explains the content of Prophet Solomon's letter, which was that the Queen of Sheba and her people should not be arrogant and haughty. Prophet Solomon hoped that they would come to him in a state of submission and surrender to Allah, whose Name had been made the opening word in his letter. They should never oppose the religion of Allah. From Solomon's letter, it is understood that this was all that Solomon asked for, which was that they should immediately believe in Allah, and he did not demand anything else.
text.32: This verse explains the implementation of the principles of *musyawarah* (consultation) in the land of Saba'. Even though Queen Balqis already had her own opinion in responding to the contents of Solomon's letter, she still consulted with her dignitaries. She said to them, "O wise leaders of my people, present your opinions and responses to the contents of Solomon's letter that has been delivered to me. I will not implement any decision except what we have agreed upon together."
text.33: Hearing Queen Balqis's words, some of the dignitaries of the Kingdom of Saba' felt offended by the contents of Solomon's letter. They felt humiliated by the letter's content, as if Solomon was ordering them to submit and obey him. In fact, they were respected people, knowledgeable, and feared by neighboring countries. They said, "O our queen, all of us present here are respected people, possessing knowledge and expertise in warfare, and having adequate equipment. Nevertheless, we leave all decisions to you. We are ready to do everything you command. Think carefully about the decision you will make."
text.34:
This verse explains the wisdom of Queen Balqis in facing her people's attitude towards the contents of Solomon's letter. She was not influenced by the arrogant attitude and feeling of strength as reflected in the words of her kingdom's dignitaries. Queen Balqis said, "O my people, this is a letter from a king. If we oppose and fight him, we might win and we might lose. If we lose, then the king and his army will destroy our country, annihilate and destroy everything we have built so far. In general, the attitude and nature of kings towards their enemies is the same, they like to oppress and cruelly kill the enemies they have defeated, as well as destroy cities and humiliate the dignitaries of the conquered countries."

Queen Balqis continued her speech, "To avoid all these undesirable events, I have an idea which, if implemented, will bring benefits to all of us. The way is to try to soften Solomon's heart by sending him gifts. These gifts will be delivered by knowledgeable people. Thus, we can know for sure their situation through our messengers. After that, we will jointly determine the appropriate action to take in facing Solomon." The dignitaries of the land of Saba' agreed with the opinion put forward by their queen.
text.35:
This verse explains the wisdom of Queen Balqis in facing her people's attitude towards the contents of Solomon's letter. She was not influenced by the arrogant attitude and feeling of strength as reflected in the statements of her kingdom's dignitaries. Queen Balqis said, "O my people, this is a letter from a king. If we oppose and fight him, we might win and we might lose. If we lose, then the king and his army will destroy our country, annihilate and destroy everything we have built so far. In general, the attitude and nature of kings towards their enemies is the same, they like to oppress and cruelly kill the enemies they have defeated, as well as destroy cities and humiliate the dignitaries of the conquered countries."

Queen Balqis continued her speech, "To avoid all these undesirable events, I have an idea which, if implemented, will bring benefits to us all. The way is to try to soften Solomon's heart by sending him gifts. These gifts will be delivered by knowledgeable people. Thus, we can know for sure their situation through our messengers. After that, we will determine together the appropriate action to take in facing Solomon." The dignitaries of the land of Saba' agreed with the opinion put forward by their queen.
text.36:
Then the delegation of Queen Balqis set out to meet Sulaiman, bringing priceless gifts. After the envoys appeared before Sulaiman, he said to them, "O envoys of Queen Balqis, do you intend to give me your wealth? I will not seek or ask for worldly pleasures and riches. I only want you all, along with your people, to follow my religion and worship Allah alone, the One God, not to worship the sun, as you do. Allah has bestowed upon me countless blessings, such as the blessings of prophethood, knowledge, and a great kingdom. Because of these blessings, I can control the jinn, speak with animals, control the wind, and many more things that Allah has bestowed upon me. If I compare the blessings I have received with the blessings you have received, then the blessings you have received are meaningless to me. Because you do not know the religion of Allah, you think that abundant wealth and worldly pleasures can satisfy your hearts. For me, wealth is meaningless and will not satisfy my heart. The pleasure and happiness I seek are eternal pleasure and happiness, in accordance with what Allah has promised to His righteous servants."

Furthermore, Sulaiman declared to the envoys of Queen Balqis, "If you do not heed my call, then return to your people. We will come with a complete army consisting of humans, jinn, and animals that you will not be able to fight. We will expel everyone who obstructs my army from their lands and homes, and they will be made humiliated, as prisoners or made slaves."
text.37:
Then the delegation of Queen Balqis set out to meet Solomon, bringing priceless gifts. After the messengers appeared before Solomon, he said to them, "O messengers of Queen Balqis, do you intend to give me your wealth? I will not seek or ask for worldly pleasures and riches. I only want all of you and your people to follow my religion and worship Allah alone, the One God, not to worship the sun, as you do. Allah has bestowed upon me countless blessings, such as the blessings of prophethood, knowledge, and a great kingdom. Because of that blessing, I can control the jinn, speak with animals, control the wind, and many more kinds of knowledge that Allah has bestowed upon me. If I compare the blessings I have received with the blessings you have received, then the blessings you have received are meaningless to me. Because you do not know the religion of Allah, you think that abundant wealth and worldly pleasures can satisfy your hearts. For me, wealth is meaningless and will not satisfy my heart. The pleasure and happiness I seek are eternal pleasure and happiness, in accordance with what Allah has promised to His righteous servants."

Furthermore, Solomon declared to the messengers of Queen Balqis, "If you do not heed my call, then return to your people. We will come with a complete army consisting of humans, jinn, and animals that you will not be able to resist. We will drive out everyone who obstructs my army from their land and homeland, and they will be made humiliated people, as prisoners or made slaves."
text.38:
After the messengers returned to their country, they conveyed to Queen Balqis what Prophet Sulaiman intended with his letter. Sulaiman requested them to accept his call to believe in Allah. They also conveyed the state of the society led by Sulaiman, as well as the state of his armies and wealth. Therefore, Queen Balqis made the decision to go to Jerusalem herself to meet Sulaiman, bringing more valuable gifts.

After Sulaiman learned that Queen Balqis would be visiting his country, he built a large and magnificent palace whose floor was made of glass. By building such a palace, he wanted to show Queen Balqis something she had never seen before.

To welcome the arrival of Queen Balqis, Sulaiman wanted to show her signs of Allah's power and greatness, and the authority that He had bestowed upon him, so that Queen Balqis and her people would believe in Allah. He intended to bring Queen Balqis' throne from her country to Jerusalem in a short time and use it as Queen Balqis' seat in his newly built palace upon the arrival of the Queen of Sheba.

Sulaiman conveyed his intention to his dignitaries, "O my dignitaries, which of you can bring the throne of Queen Balqis from her country to this place, before their delegation arrives here?"
text.39: Hearing Solomon's request, Ifrit (belonging to the jinn) who was clever replied, "I will come to you with it before you rise from your place, and indeed, I am strong and trustworthy for this." What is meant by "before you rise from your place" is before Solomon left that place. He usually left that place before noon.
text.40:
Sulaiman was not satisfied with the Ifrit's offer. He wanted the throne to arrive in an even shorter time. So he asked those present before him to accomplish it. Then a person who had acquired knowledge from al-Kitab answered, "I will bring the throne to you in the blink of an eye." What the person said proved true, and the throne of Queen Balqis was before Sulaiman. There is an opinion that this person was al-Khidhir. There is also an opinion that it was an angel, and another opinion that it was Asif bin Barqiya.

Seeing the event that occurred in the blink of an eye, Prophet Sulaiman said, "This is from the grace that my Lord has bestowed upon me, to test me whether I am among those who are grateful for the grace of God or among those who deny it." From Prophet Sulaiman's attitude, the strength of his faith and his vigilance are apparent. He was not easily deceived by any grace given to him, because all grace, whether in the form of happiness or misery, is a test from God to His servants.

Sulaiman said this because he was very sure that whoever is grateful for Allah's blessings, the benefit of being grateful for Allah's blessings will return to himself, because Allah will add more blessings. Conversely, those who deny Allah's blessings, the sin of their denial will also return to them. He will be punished by Allah for that denial.

Furthermore, Sulaiman said, "That the Lord who is worshipped is the All-Rich Lord, not needing anything from His creation, but it is the creation that needs Him. The Lord who is worshipped is the Most Generous Lord to His servants when He repays their good deeds with manifold rewards."

The attitude of Prophet Sulaiman in receiving Allah's blessings is an attitude that should be emulated by every Muslim. Such an attitude will eliminate the arrogance and pride that exists within a person. It will also eliminate feelings of despair and inferiority for those who are in a state of misery and suffering, because he knows that all of this is a trial and test from God to His servants.
text.41:
Solomon commanded the leaders of his people to alter the appearance of Bilqis' throne, which had arrived before him. He wanted to see whether Queen Bilqis would recognize that the seat she was sitting on was her throne or not.

In this way, it was hoped that Queen Bilqis would become more convinced that Solomon was a messenger of Allah. He desired nothing other than the faith of Queen Bilqis and her people.
text.42:
After Queen Balqis arrived, Solomon asked her, "Is your throne like this?" Balqis replied, "Indeed, this throne is very similar to my throne." According to Mujahid, Queen Balqis knew that the throne was hers, because there were signs indicating that the throne belonged to her. However, she was surprised why the throne was in Solomon's palace.

Seeing this reality and connecting it with her knowledge about the hoopoe bird, Balqis said, "Indeed, we were given, before this miracle occurred, the knowledge that the God who deserves to be worshipped is the One and Only God. He is All-Powerful, as is the case with the hoopoe bird, an extraordinary bird that, by the power of God, has been able to connect our country with your country, and also by observing the news we received from our messengers. All of this shows that you, O Solomon, are truly a messenger of Allah sent to us to convey His religion."

Furthermore, Balqis said, "We, together with our people, declare our faith in you. We will abandon the religion we have adhered to all this time. You no longer need to present us with other miracles, because we have already believed."
text.43: This verse explains that Queen Balqis was previously unwilling to accept Islam because the leaders of her people were disbelievers who worshipped the sun. She was worried that her people would ostracize her. Only after facing Sulaiman did she dare to declare her Islam and dare to express the contents of her heart.
text.44:
According to one narration, after Prophet Solomon learned from Allah about the arrival of Queen Balqis to his country, he ordered his people to build a large and beautiful palace. The floor was made of shiny glass that easily reflected light. Underneath the glass floor, there was a pool containing various kinds of fish, and the pool water seemed to flow like a river.

At the time of Queen Balqis' arrival, Prophet Solomon received her in the new palace and invited her to enter. Queen Balqis was surprised and astonished when entering Solomon's palace. According to her sight, there was a river stretching out that she had to cross to meet Solomon. Therefore, she lifted her skirt, revealing her calves. Seeing this, Solomon said, "What you see is not water or a river, but a glass floor with flowing water underneath." Hearing Solomon's words, Queen Balqis immediately lowered her skirt and acknowledged in her heart that Solomon's palace was bigger and better than her own.

Then Prophet Solomon invited Balqis to embrace Islam, and explained the error of worshiping the sun. Solomon's call was well received by Balqis. She regretted her past disbelief because it meant she had wronged herself. Balqis also stated that she was willing to surrender herself with Solomon to Allah, the Lord of the entire universe. To Him she would worship with the utmost sincerity.
text.45:
This verse explains that Allah sent the Prophet Salih to the people of Thamud who resided in al-Hijr, a rocky mountainous region located between Wadi al-Qura and Syria. The Prophet Salih was a descendant of Thamud, meaning he was sent to his own people. The Prophet Salih called upon his people, who worshipped something besides Allah or associated partners with Him, to worship only Allah, the One and Only God. In response to Salih's call, his people were divided into two groups:

1. A small portion of them answered his call by abandoning idol worship and worshipping only the One and Only God.

2. The majority of them remained in disbelief, even threatening and opposing the Prophet Salih.

Between these two groups, debates and animosity arose. Each group accused the other's religion of being false. Furthermore, the group that considered itself strong and had more followers increased their oppression and opposed the Prophet Salih by killing the she-camel, which they had been forbidden to kill. They also demanded that the punishment be hastened upon them, if he was truly a messenger sent by Allah.

Allah says:

"Then they hamstrung the she-camel and defied the command of their Lord and said, "O Salih, bring us what you threaten us with, if you should be of the messengers." (al-A'raf/7: 77)
text.46:
Seeing the attitude and challenges of his people, Prophet Saleh said to them, "O my people, why do you want the punishment to be hastened upon you, before you believe and do good deeds? Why do you not hasten to believe and remain in disbelief? Whereas your faith can bring you rewards and eternal happiness. While disbelief will result in sin and eternal punishment in the Hereafter."

Furthermore, Prophet Saleh called on his people to immediately ask forgiveness from Allah and repent to Him. By doing so, their sins will be forgiven by Allah and the mercy that has been given will be increased with even greater mercy.
text.47:
The disbelieving people of Thamud responded to Prophet Saleh's call by saying that they felt unlucky because of Prophet Saleh's call and those who believed in him. Ever since Prophet Saleh called on them to abandon their gods and worship only the One God, they had been afflicted with various calamities, such as the lack of rain which caused drought and others. They believed that they would continue to be struck by disaster because of the anger of their gods due to Prophet Saleh's actions. The signs of misfortune and the coming of disaster appeared every time they threw and startled birds, which gave signs of their fate; the bird showed them unfavorable signs.

They answered in this way because of their ignorance and their belief in superstition and other things. Just as primitive people believe in the unseen powers that exist in objects in nature, in addition to the unseen power that exists in Allah Himself, so too were the people of Thamud. One of the beliefs and customs of the people of Thamud was that if they were on a long journey and encountered birds flying from right to left, they were happy. This indicated that they could continue their journey. Conversely, if the bird flew and ran from left to right, it signified that there would be a disaster if they continued on their long journey.

Prophet Saleh answered his people's statement by saying that indeed whatever befell them, whether good or bad, happiness or misery, was the decree of Allah and that was His *qadha* and *qadar*. No one can change Allah's *qadha* and *qadar*. If He wills, He will give sustenance. If He wills, they will not be given even a little sustenance. He and his followers had no power whatsoever to bring misfortune or good fortune to them.

Then Prophet Saleh explained that the misfortune was a test from God for them, whether they would follow his call and no longer do the forbidden deeds that they usually did, or whether they would not follow him.
text.48:
This verse explains the reasons for the widespread destruction in their land, because in the city of Hijr there were nine people who liked to cause chaos in society. These nine people were the children of the powerful nobles in that land. They could do any good or bad deed freely, and no one could stop them. The evil deeds they committed were always protected and defended by their powerful parents in that land. Thus, these nine people became the source of evil and tyranny.

There are several narrations that explain the names of these nine people, as explained by al-Gaznawi, Ibn Ishaq, Zamakhsyari, al-Mawardi, and others. Each of them presents different names. However, the important thing from all of this is that the corruption and sinful acts committed by these nine criminals were known and approved by the leaders of the land of Thamud. Because they came from the powerful nobility in that land, they had a very great influence on the people of Thamud.
text.49:
This verse explains the plot being discussed by those nine people, after they committed a forbidden act by killing the camel that Prophet Saleh forbade them to kill. They received a threat from Prophet Saleh that they would be destroyed by Allah within three days after the camel was killed.

Among them, one said, "Let us all swear solemnly that we will kill Prophet Saleh and his followers one night. Then, tomorrow, we will say to his slain family that we know nothing about the incident, and it is impossible for us to commit injustice against our own family. We will also say to them that we are all truthful people."
text.50: Allah clarifies that the plan of treachery and deceit devised by the people of Thamud was to kill the Prophet Salih and those who believed with him. However, they forgot that Allah has a plan and will that they cannot hinder in the slightest, in accordance with His sunnah, which is that He will inflict torment and punishment upon those who deny the call of the messengers He sent. In this world, they will be struck by calamities that come without them realizing it, while in the Hereafter they will face a painful torment.
text.51:
This verse commands the Muslims to reflect upon the story of Prophet Saleh and his people. Allah inflicted upon the people of Prophet Saleh a devastating punishment that destroyed them to their very roots ('azb isti'sal). This punishment was a consequence of their disobedience to Prophet Saleh and their deceitful plot to destroy him and those who believed with him. Allah destroyed them with a thunderous strike of unimaginable force. In accordance with Sunnatullah (Allah's established way), such calamities and punishments will also befall the polytheists of Mecca if they persist in their disbelief and opposition to the call of Prophet Muhammad.

There is a narration stating that Prophet Saleh built a mosque in one of the valleys in al-Hijr. He used to perform prayers in that mosque. After he delivered Allah's warning, he and his family, along with those who believed with him, went to that mosque. Because of his departure, his people deliberated and decided to kill Prophet Saleh before the third day of the day he had promised. So, some of his people went to the valley of the mosque to carry out that plan. However, on their way, they were struck by a large stone before they could carry out their intention. The rest of his people were destroyed by Allah with a thunderous strike. Prophet Saleh and his followers escaped and were saved from the punishment.
text.52:
This verse explains the consequences experienced by the people of Thamud and their land. Because of the terrible thunderbolt, they died in their homes. No one could save themselves or tend to their corpses, because they were all dead. The corpses decayed and dissolved into the earth. The remains of their homes and land can be witnessed by travelers, as documentation of the truth of the Qur'an's story about the people of Thamud who were destroyed by Allah due to their denial and disobedience to Prophet Saleh, who called them to the religion of Allah.

In the story explained by Allah in these verses, which was conveyed by Prophet Muhammad to his people, there is truly a lesson and a moral for mankind. This verse reminds us of the *sunnatullah* that will certainly apply to those who deny the commands of Allah and who constantly commit His prohibitions, including the polytheists of Mecca.
text.53:
This verse explains that Allah saved Prophet Saleh and those who believed with him from that great calamity. Allah saved them because they refused to do deeds that aroused Allah's anger, which would have resulted in them being afflicted with His punishment. They protected themselves from Allah's wrath by carrying out all His commands and avoiding His prohibitions.

This verse alludes to Prophet Muhammad and the believers that the polytheists of Mecca would receive torment and calamity like that received by previous peoples if they remained unbelieving. Allah would save Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, along with the believers, just as He saved Prophet Saleh and his people. The polytheists of Mecca who persisted in their polytheism would be destroyed by Allah.

After the destruction of his people, Prophet Saleh and the believers went to a place called Ramallah in Palestine and settled in that land. Until now, the tomb of Prophet Saleh can still be found near the city of Ramallah. This tomb also serves as documentation of the events of Prophet Saleh and his people.
text.54:
This verse explains the moral depravity of the people of Lot. Therefore, Lot warned them sternly to stop their actions. The actions of the people of Lot were:

1.  They committed homosexual acts, even though they knew that such acts were forbidden.

2.  They committed these homosexual acts in public, at various gatherings, as if they were encouraging others to do the same.

3.  If they could not perform these acts on someone voluntarily, they would force them. Therefore, if guests stopped in their land, they would try to get the guests to comply with their desires. If the guests refused, they would force them.
text.55:
This verse explains that the actions and deeds of the people of Lot were contrary to Allah's purpose in creating mankind, consisting of men and women. With the existence of women and men, humans will be able to form families and establish loving relationships between family members, such as the loving relationship between husband and wife, the loving and affectionate relationship between parents and children, and other family members. Only then will life be felt to have meaning. Allah says:

And of His signs is that He created for you mates from among yourselves that you may find tranquility in them; and He placed between you affection and mercy. Indeed in that are signs for a people who give thought. (ar-Rum/30: 21).

This reality is what the people of Lot denied, as if they did not believe in the truth of Allah's law. Therefore, Lot said to them, "O my people, in reality, by such actions, you are people who do not want to know the purpose of the Lord in creating mankind consisting of men and women. You do not know your position in society, and you do not know the great plan that will befall mankind and humanity, if you continue to do such deeds."
text.56:
Hearing Lot's statement, his people became angry, and as if they did not understand even a little of what Lot's warning meant. Therefore, they threatened Lot with the words, "Let us expel Lot and his family from our land, because he forbids us from doing the deeds that we have enjoyed all this time." They assumed that Lot and his family could live safely and peacefully in their land only because of their kindness and compassion. They thought that if they no longer extended that generosity and compassion to Lot and his family, he would certainly become miserable. This is what they meant by the order to expel Lot.

They mocked by saying that Lot and his followers were clean people, so they did not want to do the deeds that they did, because they considered them dirty.
text.57:
Because the people of Lot remained in denial and committed transgressions, Allah destroyed them and saved Lot and those who were with him, except for his wife. His wife was among those who disbelieved, so she remained with her disbelieving people. She too was struck by the terrible disaster.

The punishment of Allah inflicted upon the people of Lot was a rain of stones made of hard clay. Their condition while being afflicted with the punishment was terrifying. Such was the recompense received by those who were disobedient.
text.58:
Because the people of Lot remained in disbelief and committed transgressions, Allah destroyed them and saved Lot and those who were with him, except for his wife. His wife was among those who disbelieved, so she remained with her disbelieving people. She too was struck by the terrible calamity.

The punishment of Allah inflicted upon the people of Lot was a rain of stones made of hard clay. Their condition while being afflicted with the punishment was terrifying. Such is the recompense received by those who are disobedient.
text.59:
This verse commands Prophet Muhammad and his ummah to utter the praises mentioned within it. These praises are *al-hamdulillah*, all praise is due only to Allah who has sent His messengers with guidance and the religion that He has made victorious over all other religions, even though the disbelievers and polytheists dislike that victory. The religion brought by the Prophets is the true religion. May Allah bestow safety and well-being upon the messengers He sent and upon His servants who truly believe. This verse is in line with another verse:

"Exalted is your Lord, the Lord of Might, above what they describe. And peace upon the messengers. And praise to Allah, Lord of the worlds." (as-Saffat/37: 180-182).

This verse is a good teaching and high moral character. Therefore, the scholars encourage believers to end all their actions, such as speaking, writing books, and so on, by praising Allah and sending blessings upon the Messenger.

Then this verse commands people to think and compare which is better, Allah or something they associate with Him. Although outwardly this verse commands people to compare Allah with idols, the intention is that with the explanations and evidence that have been presented, if the disbelievers would use their minds, they would surely come to the conclusion that Allah is the One who deserves to be worshipped, not idols that are unable to do anything.

It is narrated that when the Messenger of Allah recited this verse, he would say:

"Rather, Allah is better, more eternal, more magnificent, and more noble than what they associate with Him. All praise is due to Allah, but most of them do not know." (Narrated by al-Baihaqi from 'Ali bin al-Husain)
text.60:
In this verse, Allah poses several questions that stir their attention to His existence, by drawing attention to the important things around them. The questions revolve around who created the heavens, the earth, and everything contained within them, and who sends down rain from the sky for mankind, so that through the rain, beautiful gardens grow, whose trees humans themselves could never grow.

This verse deserves attention, especially from those who frequently travel around as tourists or otherwise, when they see beautiful scenery, such as botanical gardens, zoos, aquariums, various exhibitions of agricultural industry products, textiles, and so on. They should view the natural beauty in front of and around them as a mirror that reflects all the beauty, majesty, and perfection of Allah. By practicing this way, human memory will always be directed to Allah. Thus, when a person sees every creature, he will surely remember its Creator. If this has become a habit, then he will feel a pure monotheism, free from all elements of polytheism (shirk). Then the question should be continued with the second question: "Is there another god besides Allah?" Of course, the answer is: "No, because only Allah is the only God who deserves to be worshipped."

Actually, those who worship idols are people who deviate from the truth. Because, if they are asked, "Who sends down rain from the sky which then revives the earth that was dead with that water," they will answer, "Allah," according to His word:

And if you ask them, "Who sends down rain from the sky and with it gives life to the earth after its lifelessness?" they will surely say, "Allah." (al-'Ankabut/29: 63)

The idol worshippers actually acknowledge that their idols cannot send down rain which is the cause of the earth's prosperity, but why do they still worship them? Their answer is only because they follow the customs of their ancestors, even though it is not in line with the logic of a healthy-minded person.
text.61:
In this verse, Allah poses the second question to expose the error of idol worshippers. Is it fitting to worship idols that provide neither benefit nor harm, or the Lord who made the earth a dwelling place for humans and animals, the Lord who made rivers in its valleys to be a source of drinking water for humans and livestock, and to irrigate plants, the Lord who made mountains to stabilize the earth, which contains many benefits with its forests above and various metals and minerals within, and the Lord who made a barrier between the salty seawater and the river that carries fresh water to its estuary? The fresh river water does not immediately become salty upon reaching the sea. In contemplating all these natural events, does the thought of a god besides Allah still occur? In reality, they do not know the value of the greatness of Allah the Creator, thus equating Him with idols that provide absolutely no benefit or harm.

According to scientific studies, the earth in this verse can be understood as land. In general, land is a place for humans to reside. Rivers on land are always located in the lowest parts of the earth's surface, which are gaps between mountains and higher plains. Furthermore, seas are separated from one another by land barriers such as peninsulas, islands, or due to the geographical distribution of continents. The distribution and shape of land and islands on the earth are generally considered to occur spontaneously as part or as a result of natural processes, but in essence, it is by the will of Allah.

This verse explains the state of the earth that is suitable for habitation by human beings. This is certainly closely related to the creation of the heavens and the earth, which is so perfect. If even a slight change were to occur in the "trajectory" of the sun and moon in relation to the earth, or if its shape were to change, or if one of its elements were to change, or if its speed of rotation on its axis were to change, or if its rotation around the sun were to change, or if the moon's rotation around it were to change, then this earth would certainly not be stable and would not be suitable for habitation for any life.
text.62: In this verse, Allah poses the third question in order to unveil the veil of misguidance of idol worshippers. The previous two questions concerned the material realm, while this third question concerns the spiritual realm. This question revolves around who answers the prayer of a person in distress when he prays to Him. Like a passenger on a ship in the middle of the sea being attacked by a violent hurricane, on the verge of sinking, who then prays for safety to Allah. Can idols save him from the danger of death, or is it Allah Himself? And who made mankind as a khalifah (successor/steward) on earth? Is there a god besides Allah who can steer and regulate everything on this earth? Only a few people remember Him.
text.63:
In this verse, Allah poses the fourth question in order to unveil the veil of misguidance of idol worshippers. This question revolves around who guides people on journeys in the darkness of land and sea when they stray from the right path? Is it not Allah who created the stars in the sky which are used as guides, as mentioned in His word:

"And it is He who has placed for you the stars that you may be guided by them through the darknesses of the land and sea." (al-An'am/6: 97)

Can the idols they worship guide them in the darkness of land and sea? Certainly not. If so, why are they worshipped? And who sends the winds bearing good tidings to the farmers before the rain falls, which is a great mercy from the Lord? Can the idols do such a thing? Is there another god besides Allah? Exalted and High is Allah above what they associate with Him.
text.64:
In this verse, Allah poses the fifth question in order to demonstrate His justice and oneness, which is: who created mankind from the beginning until the creation of the most beautiful form, then causes them to die when He wills, and then resurrects them on the Day of Judgment after they have become bones? Who provides sustenance to mankind from the heavens and the earth by sending down rain from the sky which causes the fertility of the soil that grows plants whose fruits can be eaten by humans and livestock? Is there another god besides Allah?

After posing the five questions above, which should be deeply considered until they become evidence of His power and oneness, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad to ask the idolaters for the reasons and proofs of the truth of their idols, "Bring forth your proof if you are truthful."

This is how the Qur'an poses questions whose answers must be sought by humans themselves. First, the water that falls to the earth so that life arises in the form of beautiful gardens. Second, making the earth a pleasant place to live with rivers, mountains, lakes, and seas. Third, humans are made caliphs on earth, namely as rulers and God's representatives to implement His laws on earth. Humans, as the highest creatures created by Allah, travel on land and sail the sea to spread the da'wah of God's laws. Lastly, even though humans, when their time comes, die and are buried in the earth so that their bodies are destroyed and become soil, they will be resurrected on the Day of Judgment. Such is the power of Allah.
text.65:
In this verse, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to explain to the polytheists of Mecca that no one knows the unseen, neither in the heavens nor on earth, except Allah, in accordance with His word:

"And with Him are the keys of the unseen; none knows them except Him." (al-An'am/6: 59)

And His word also:

"Indeed, Allah [alone] has knowledge of the Hour. And He sends down the rain and knows what is in the wombs. And no soul knows what it will earn tomorrow, and no soul knows in what land it will die. Indeed, Allah is Knowing and Acquainted." (Luqman/31: 34)

The meaning of the unseen here refers to matters related to the state and life in the Hereafter and matters in the world that are within the human environment and can be felt but are beyond human ability to reach. It is narrated from Masruq from 'Aisha, she said:

From 'Aisha r.a., she said, "Whoever thinks that Prophet Muhammad saw knew what would happen tomorrow, then he has told a great lie against Allah, because Allah stated, 'Say, none in the heavens and earth knows the unseen except Allah.'" (Narrated by Muslim)

In this verse, one of the unseen things mentioned is that they do not know when they will be resurrected from the graves on the Day of Judgment, because the Day of Judgment comes suddenly, in accordance with Allah's word:

"Do they [then] await except the Hour - that it should come upon them suddenly while they perceive not?" (az-Zukhruf/43: 66)
text.66:
In this verse, Allah explains their ignorance about the Day of Judgment. There are two opinions in understanding this verse. First, their knowledge of the Hereafter is not comprehensive. Second, their knowledge of the Resurrection is perfect, but when they do not see it with their own eyes in the world, they deny it. Not only do they not believe and not know when the Resurrection will occur, but they are also very doubtful, which ultimately leads to a state of complete blindness about the Day of Judgment. Whatever evidence is shown to them about the coming of the Day of Judgment, they still reject it.

Belief in the coming of the Resurrection is very necessary for every person who wants to educate himself to become an honest and responsible human being. When he is convinced that he will be examined on the Day of Judgment, he will always restrain his desires from any deviation and wickedness. The state and all its citizens will not be harmed by all his attitudes and behavior. All his wisdom leads towards security, prosperity, and shared happiness. Religion is an absolute element in nation-building.
text.67:
In this verse, Allah explains the denial of the disbelievers regarding the Day of Resurrection from the graves. They said, "After we have died and become dust, and so have our forefathers, will we really be brought forth [again] alive from the graves?" Their question was uttered cynically, implying that the event was impossible, as stated in Allah's words:

"And they say, "When we are bones and crumbled fragments, will we really be resurrected [in] a new creation?" (al-Isra'/17: 49)
text.68: In this verse, Allah explains the reason why the disbelievers deny the Day of Resurrection, with their statement that they have indeed always been given such threats since their ancestors. That is nothing but the fables of the ancients, which are completely without basis in reality.
text.69: In this verse, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to give advice and guidance to those who deny the Day of Resurrection. The Prophet (peace be upon him) instructs them to travel the earth and observe the fate of the sinful among the previous nations who denied Allah and the messengers He sent. How those nations experienced destruction as a consequence of their disbelief in Allah and the Day of Resurrection. These events should serve as a lesson for them. However, they remain in denial, so they will experience destruction, based on *sunnatullah* (Allah's established way) which remains in effect.
text.70:
In this verse, the Prophet Muhammad is commanded by Allah to be patient and calm in facing various challenges and mockery from the disbelievers. The Prophet is forbidden from being saddened and despairing in the face of their deception because Allah will surely provide help so that the religion of Islam will spread widely to all corners of the earth, even though the disbelievers dislike it, as stated in His word:

"It is He who has sent His Messenger with guidance and the religion of truth to manifest it over all religion, although those who associate others with Allah dislike it." (at-Taubah/9: 33)
text.71: This verse explains that the Quraysh not only denied the Day of Resurrection, but they even challenged the Prophet Muhammad to bring the punishment that had been threatened upon them. This challenge demonstrates their attitude of truly denying the existence of the Day of Resurrection. Furthermore, they made a demand of the Prophet Muhammad to hasten the coming of Allah's threat with their words, "When will this punishment come which you threaten us with, if you should be truthful?"
text.72: Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad to answer the questions of the Quraysh by saying that the punishment they were waiting for and wanted to be hastened would surely come soon. In reality, that punishment manifested as the destruction and defeat they would experience during the Battle of Badr. As many as 70 of their leaders, including Abu Jahl, were killed, and 70 others became prisoners of war.
text.73:
In this verse, Allah explains that the punishment they requested to be hastened was not sent down because He truly possesses great bounty for mankind. Allah, the Most Forbearing, does not immediately send down His punishment, but instead gives them the opportunity to repent and realize their error, so that with full awareness they accept Allah's guidance brought by His Prophet. The opportunity to repent and return to the path of truth is a great bounty, but most people are ungrateful for it. This is also mentioned in His word:

...Indeed, Allah is bountiful to mankind, but most of the people are not grateful. (al-Baqarah/2: 243)
text.74:
In this verse, Allah explains that He truly knows what they conceal in their hearts and what they declare. He knows what they hide regarding their animosity towards the Messenger of Allah and what they manifest in their actions and schemes. Allah will recompense them according to their deeds. This is in accordance with His saying:

It is all the same (to Allah) whether any of you conceal his speech or declare it openly, whether he hides by night or walks about freely by day. (ar-Ra'd/13: 10)
text.75:
This verse explains that all unseen events that occur in the heavens and the earth have been recorded in Lauh Mahfuz, in accordance with His word:

"Do you not know that Allah knows what is in the heaven and earth? Indeed, that is in a Record (Lauh Mahfudh). Indeed, that is easy for Allah." (This part is incomplete in the original Indonesian text).
text.76:
In these two verses, Allah explains the special characteristics of the Qur'an as the greatest miracle of Prophet Muhammad, namely:

1.  The Qur'an provides certainty to the Children of Israel about various matters they have disputed, especially those related to Isa al-Masih, the son of Maryam. Some of the People of the Book consider him to be God, others consider him to be the son of God, and still others consider him to be the third person in the Trinity. Some also consider him to be a false prophet, just as his mother, Maryam, was accused of committing adultery.

2.  The Qur'an is truly a guide for believers because it contains various arguments and proofs that demonstrate the truth of *tauhid* (monotheism), which is the core message of the prophets. The Qur'an also contains laws that are greatly needed by all of mankind to achieve happiness in this world and the hereafter. This convinces those who read the Qur'an that this book is indeed a revelation from Allah.

3.  The Qur'an is also a mercy for the believers. Although Prophet Muhammad was an *ummi* (unlettered) who could not read or write, and had never associated with the leaders of the People of the Book before becoming a messenger, because the Qur'an is the word of Allah revealed to Prophet Muhammad, it contains complete stories of the prophets and past peoples as described in the Torah and the Gospel.

Disagreements among the People of the Book are indeed very deep and concern fundamental matters such as the opinion about the Trinity, the existence of God the Father and God the Son. There are also those who consider Isa al-Masih as a false prophet, the last prophet is Yusya, and so on.

If the People of the Book studied their scriptures honestly and sincerely to seek the truth without national or tribal sentiments, they would surely come to the conclusion that the prophet indicated in the Torah is none other than Prophet Muhammad because the characteristics mentioned in the Torah are indeed the same as his characteristics. However, because Prophet Muhammad was not from the descendants of the Children of Israel, they found it difficult to accept that truth. In the Old Testament, Deuteronomy 18:18 states, "I will raise up for them a prophet like you from among their brothers. And I will put my words in his mouth, and he shall speak to them all that I command him. And whoever will not listen to my words that he shall speak in my name, I myself will require it of him."

The indication from the book of Deuteronomy contains the understanding that the prophet who will be sent by Allah after Prophet Musa is from the brothers of the Children of Israel, namely the Bani Ismail or the Arab people, because Israel or Jacob and Ismail are both descendants of Prophet Ibrahim. Ismail is the son of Ibrahim and Jacob is the son of Isaac, who is also the son of Ibrahim. The prophet who will be sent is like Musa.

If they are aware and repent and distance themselves from the temptations of lust and tribal sentiments, they will feel the truth and purity of the teachings of the Qur'an. However, because they are hindered by arrogance, they still reject it, even though the proofs of its truth are clearly visible.

text.80:
In this verse, Allah explains that Prophet Muhammad was not tasked with making the polytheists believe. He was only tasked with conveying the call or message from Allah. It was not within his authority to force disbelievers to become believers. That is within Allah's power. The Prophet was not able to insert guidance into the hearts of those who were already sealed shut. This verse also explains that Muhammad could not make the dead hear, nor could he make the deaf hear the call, especially if their hearts had turned away.

The phrases "the dead" and "the deaf" in this verse are metaphorical expressions. The meaning is that the polytheists are considered to be those whose minds are dead, who are deaf and cannot hear the call and invitation to goodness. They have turned away. They are likened to the dead and the deaf because all the verses recited to them have no effect whatsoever.

Although in general this verse explains that the dead cannot hear the call of the living, there are several authentic hadiths, such as those narrated by Muslim, which explain that Prophet Muhammad once spoke to the corpses of the polytheists who were killed in the Battle of Badr and buried together in a well. Seeing this, some of the companions, including Umar bin Khattab, expressed their astonishment by asking why the Messenger of Allah was speaking to the dead. In response, the Messenger of Allah said:

"You are no more able to hear what I say than they are, except that they cannot answer." (Narrated by Imam Muslim from Anas bin Malik)

The meaning contained in the hadith above is that the living and the dead are equally able to hear the Prophet's words. However, the living can answer, while they cannot. In several authentic hadiths, it is also explained by the Prophet that when a corpse has been placed in its grave, it can hear the sound of the shoes or sandals of the people who escorted it.

As a conveyor of Allah's message, the Prophet could not give guidance to the polytheists to become believers, as happened with the Prophet's uncle, Abu Talib, who until the end of his life did not believe. Allah says:

"Indeed, [O Muhammad], you do not guide whom you like, but Allah guides whom He wills. And He is most knowing of who are [rightly] guided." (al-Qasas/28: 56)

The Prophet's task is only to give guidance in the sense of providing direction (irsyad), providing explanation (bayan), and implementing it, as Allah says:

"...And indeed, [O Muhammad], you guide to a straight path." (asy-Syura/42: 52)

The meaning of hidayah in Surah al-Qasas/28: 56 above is "taufik". This implies that the Prophet does not have the authority to give taufik to humans, even to those he loves, such as Abu Talib. Only Allah can give hidayah in the sense of taufik to those whom He wills.

As for hidayah in Surah as-Syura/42: 52, it means "tabyin and irsyad". This means that the Prophet has the authority to provide explanations with extensive guidance.
text.81: In this verse, Allah reinforces the understanding of the previous verse that Prophet Muhammad is completely unable to turn away the blind, whose hearts have been locked from error. Their inner eyes cannot be guided to the straight path because there is a hijab or wall covering their vision, so they cannot see the truth at all. Prophet Muhammad cannot make someone hear his call with positive hearing, except for those who believe in Allah, and then surrender sincerely and purely to Him.
text.82:
In this verse, Allah explains that when His anger and wrath have been cast upon disobedient humans, because they abandoned His commands and defiled the purity of His religion, then as the Day of Judgment approaches, crawling creatures will emerge from the earth and speak to them with eloquent tongues, stating that most humans are not convinced by Allah's verses and do not believe in the coming of the Day of Judgment. The speech of the crawling creature contains harsh rebukes and warnings to the humans around it. The strangeness that will occur before the Day of Judgment, where a crawling creature can speak to warn disobedient people, is not impossible for Allah. He can give the creature the ability to speak at that time, in accordance with His word:

"They will say, "Allah, Who has given speech to all things, has given us speech." (Fussilat/41: 21)

Regarding the emergence of the crawling creature, it is considered a matter of the unseen because its form and characteristics are not mentioned in the Qur'an. Information about this is only found in hadith. Among them is the hadith narrated by Muslim from 'Abdullah bin 'Amr:

'Abdullah bin 'Amr said, "I memorized a hadith from the Messenger of Allah (saw) that I will not forget. I heard him say, 'The first signs of (the coming of the Day of Judgment) that will appear are the rising of the sun from the west and the emergence of the crawling creature to humans in the morning. When one of these two events occurs, the other will immediately follow after it.'" (Riwayat Muslim)

After conveying the very frightening news about the horrors of the Day of Judgment, Allah in this verse presents evidence of His Oneness, about the certainty of the coming Day of Resurrection, and evidence that confirms Muhammad saw as the Messenger of Allah. In this verse, Allah describes the events of the Day of Judgment specifically, namely on the day the trumpet is blown by the angel Israfil. Everything in the heavens and the earth will be shocked, except for the angels Jibril, Mikail, Israfil, Izrail, and those who believe. The blowing of the trumpet will occur twice, the first blowing, named "nafkhah as-sa'q," will cause the death of all creatures except those who are exempted. Then, with the second blowing, they will all be resurrected from their respective graves, as in His saying:

And the Horn will be blown, and whoever is in the heavens and whoever is on the earth will fall dead except whom Allah wills. Then it will be blown again, and at once they will be standing, looking on. (az-Zumar/39:68)

This second blowing is named "nafkhah al-ba'ts," meaning the blowing of resurrection, as in His saying:

And the Horn will be blown, and at once from the graves to their Lord they will hasten. (Yasin/36:51)

This event is also mentioned in Allah's saying:

The Day they will emerge from the graves rapidly as if they were, toward an [appointed] idol, hastening. Their eyes lowered, humiliation will cover them. That is the Day which they had been promised. (al-Ma'arij/70:43-44)
text.88:
In this verse, Allah explains that the mountains, which now appear to stand firmly in their places, will be uprooted from the earth on the Day of Judgment and then flown like feathers in the air, like the movement of clouds. Allah says:

And the mountains will be like wool, driven about. (al-Ma'arij/70: 9)

There are two opinions among the scholars of tafsir regarding the statement in this verse that the mountains will be flown in the air like the movement of clouds, or in another verse, like feathers blown by the wind. The first opinion, which is the opinion of most mufassirs, states that this verse relates to the events of the Day of Judgment, as in Allah's saying:

On the Day the sky will shake with violent shaking, and the mountains will move. (ath-Thur/52: 9-10)

And His saying:

And the mountains will be made to pass away, and will be but as a mirage. (an-Naba'/78: 20)

In His other saying:

On the Day when the earth will be changed to another earth, and so will be the heavens, and they (mankind) will appear before Allah, the One, the Prevailing. (Ibrahim/14: 48)

These very terrible events occur on the Day of Judgment after the trumpet is blown for the second time, when all people are raised from their graves and they witness all kinds of very terrible events with different attitudes.

The second opinion regarding the tafsir of verse 88, which is the opinion of astronomers, states that this verse is not related to the events of the Day of Judgment, but to natural phenomena in the world. This verse says, "And you see the mountains, thinking them firmly fixed, while they pass away as the passing away of the clouds." It is used as evidence that the earth rotates like other planets on a predetermined orbit, only that humans as inhabitants of the earth do not feel it.

The reason for the astronomers' opinion, that verse 88 is related to current events and not to the events of the Day of Judgment, is:

1. This verse cannot be included in the category of threats or frightening with the awesomeness of the Day of Judgment because it is followed by the words: "(Such is) the work of Allah, who perfected all things." Therefore, this verse is more appropriate when connected to the present time, where humans as inhabitants of the earth think that the earth is still, as are the mountains on its surface. In fact, the earth together with the mountains moves or revolves like the movement of clouds.

2. The mountains are flown to be destroyed on the Day of Judgment, and this occurs simultaneously with the destruction of the universe, including the death of all humans. Only a few angels remain alive. If on the day after the first blowing of the trumpet there are no more humans alive, how can it be said that later they will see the mountains that they thought were still, while they are moving like the movement of clouds.

3. The people in Padang Mahsyar who witness the mountains moving like the movement of clouds, of course, are aware and see with their own eyes, so it is not appropriate to say that they think the mountains are just still in their places. It is very different if it is connected to the present time, because humans cannot feel that the mountains are moving and walking in space like the movement of clouds, because the mountains move together with the earth, and the air around them. With such an understanding, it is then appropriate with the words: "(Such is) the work of Allah, who perfected all things." These beautiful words are not appropriate to be put forward in the context of the Day of Judgment which is full of threats and fear of the destruction of the entire universe.

Thus, these are the two opinions about the tafsir of verse 88. Most mufassirs explain that the verse is related to the events of the Day of Judgment. Some others, consisting of astronomers, explain that the verse is related to current events, and is used as evidence that everything on earth, including mountains, moves, walking in space like the movement of clouds. The difference in interpretation does not concern the level of meaning, but only concerns the time of occurrence. Because this event is included in the unseen realm, it is better for human attention to be focused on improving their deeds. Therefore, at the end of the verse it is stated that Allah is indeed All-Knowing of what humans do.

According to scientists, the earth is the fifth largest planet out of the nine planets in the solar system. Its shape is similar to a round ball, with a circumference of about 12,743 km. The earth's surface area is estimated to be around 510 million km2. About 29% of the earth's surface is land, while the rest is ocean.

The earth consists of several layers which are broadly divided into 3 parts. The uppermost part is called the earth's crust and its thickness varies from 0-100 km where it becomes thicker towards the continents. Below it is the mantle with a depth of up to 2,900 km. The deepest part is called the earth's core with a depth of 2,900-6,370 km. This division is based on the analysis of earthquake waves and each part has different physical properties. The earth's core, for example, has physical properties like a liquid object. This division can basically be detailed further. Humans are located on the upper part of the earth's layer, namely the earth's crust.

Until the mid-20th century, the field of earth science was marked by debates about continental drift. Those who disagreed were called fixists, while those who agreed were called mobilists. According to the mobilist camp, continents float and move on the mantle. If we look at a world map, it is very easy to see that the continents of Africa and [South] America, when juxtaposed, have relatively overlapping coastlines. So, basically all the existing continents were originally one continent, called Pangea, then broke apart and moved to the places we see now. Scientific data such as paleomagnetic data, fossil similarities and geological formation similarities support this theory. And you see the mountains, thinking them firmly fixed, while they pass away as the passing away of the clouds.

This debate continued and peaked in the sixties. At that time, there was a revolution of thought in the field of geology and the thinking of the mobilists began to be widely accepted. The discovery of the mid-ocean ridge in the Atlantic Ocean and the Pacific Ocean, supported by geological and geophysical data, especially magnetic data, showed the expansion of the ocean floor where two plates move away from each other. On this ocean floor, magma with very high temperatures originating from the earth's mantle rises up to form the mid-ocean ridge.

From the two concepts above, Continental Drift and Seafloor Spreading, the concept of Plate Tectonics was born, which developed very rapidly since 1967 and has implications for all aspects of geology including earthquakes, volcanoes, to the development of hydrocarbon basins and mineral deposits. This theory states that the upper part of the earth consists of lithospheric plates consisting of the earth's crust and the upper mantle which float and move on the part of the mantle called the asthenosphere.

The lithospheric plates move and interact with each other. At places where they meet, the meeting of these plates causes earthquakes. An example is Indonesia, which is the meeting point of three plates: Eurasia, Pacific, and Indo-Australia. When two plates meet, there is continuous pressure (load), and when the plates can no longer withstand the pressure (load), the load that has been accumulated for hundreds of years is released, and released in the form of an earthquake, as Allah says:

When the earth is shaken with its (final) earthquake, and the earth discharges its burdens, and man will say, "What is [wrong] with it?" That Day, it will report its news. (al-Zalzalah/99: 1-4)

On that day, the earth will tell its news. The heavy burden released in the form of an earthquake is a geological process that takes years. And so on, every time the load is released, the process of collecting the load occurs again. This geological process or geological news can be recorded, both naturally and using geophysical or geodetic equipment. An example is the earthquakes that occurred several decades or hundreds of years ago, the event of load release was well recorded by coral reefs located near the earthquake source. In modern times, this energy release is recorded by seismograph equipment (earthquake recorders) and geodetic equipment called GPS (Global Position System).

text.90: On the contrary, whoever associates partners with Allah and commits evil deeds, their faces will be thrust into Hell, and it will be said to them, "You will not be recompensed except according to the polytheism and evil deeds that you used to do in the world, which became the cause of Allah's wrath."
text.91:
In this verse, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to convey to the polytheists of Mecca that he is only commanded by Allah to worship the Lord of this land (Mecca), which has been made a Haram (Sacred Land), where bloodshed or injustice against anyone is forbidden. The specific mention of the city of Mecca in this verse is because the Ka'bah is located there, which is the first house of worship built on earth as a place for people to face when praying wherever they are, in accordance with His saying:

Indeed, the first House [of worship] established for mankind was that at Bakkah [Makkah] - blessed and a guidance for the worlds. (ali 'Imran/3: 96)

As for what must be worshipped, it is only Allah, not the idols that the polytheists placed there, in accordance with Allah's saying:

So let them worship the Lord of this House, Who has fed them, [saving them] from hunger and made them safe, [saving them] from fear. (Quraisy/106: 3-4).

This is a strong rebuke to the disbelievers of Mecca who do not worship Allah, the Owner of the Baitullah, but worship the idols they placed around it. To Allah belongs everything, both in the heavens and the earth, in terms of creation, ownership, and management; there is no partner for Him. Therefore, only Allah is the only one who deserves to be worshipped, and to Him the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was commanded to surrender with full sincerity and monotheism, which is the straight path or the religion of Islam, in accordance with His saying:

Say, "Indeed, my Lord has guided me to a straight path - a correct religion - the way of Abraham, inclining toward truth. And he was not among those who associated others with Allah." (al-An'am/6: 161)
text.92:
In this verse, Allah explains that Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was commanded to recite the Qur'an to mankind, to reveal the meanings and secrets contained within it, and to absorb the proofs of Allah's power that can be seen in the universe. Thus, he could delve into the true essence of life and receive the abundant blessings of Allah upon him.

The Prophet (peace be upon him) repeated the recitation of that verse several dozen times until dawn. When he recited it, some of the secrets contained within it became apparent to him, so that he felt the benefit of reading the verses of the Qur'an and understanding its contents, in accordance with His saying:

"Thus do We recite to you (O Muhammad) of the verses and the Reminder [i.e., the Qur'an] full of wisdom." (ali 'Imran/3: 58)

Another saying of Allah:

"Thus We have sent you (O Muhammad) to a community before which [other] communities have passed on - that you might recite to them that which We have revealed to you." (ar-Ra'd/13: 30)

Whoever follows the teachings of the Qur'an, believes in Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), and accepts his guidance, then indeed he has taken the straight path towards happiness in this world and the hereafter. That guidance is for his own good. However, whoever goes astray, and deviates from the straight path that has been pioneered by the Prophet, then the harm will be felt by themselves. The Prophet (peace be upon him) will not suffer any loss because his duty is only to give warning, in accordance with Allah's saying:

"Then, [O Muhammad], your duty is only to convey [the message], and it is for Us to take account." (ar-Ra'd/13: 40)

And the saying of Allah:

"You are only a warner, and Allah is Disposer of all things." (Hud/11: 12)
text.93:
In this verse, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad, who has delivered glad tidings to the Muslims who follow His guidance and warnings to those who deny it, to say that all praise is due to Allah for all the abundance of His grace and favor. Among these are the blessings of prophethood and apostleship, which lead to other blessings, both worldly and in the Hereafter.

Allah has granted the Prophet the ability to bear all burdens in carrying out the call of religion, in obedience and submission to the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful Lord, Who has provided His sincere servants with His pleasure and great rewards. Allah has given the Prophet various miracles, which demonstrate the truth of his message and the ability to follow the straight path of religion. The Messenger earnestly desires that his people open their hearts to see the proofs of truth. However, Satan and their own desires have so blinded their eyes that they cannot see the reality.

If they still remain defiant and stubborn, then remember that all humans will die. On the Day of Judgment, they will all be resurrected from their respective graves and brought before Allah, who will examine all the deeds they did in the world. There, Allah will show the defiant ones the signs of His greatness. There, Allah will also show them His most severe punishment, so that they will know it. There, too, they will express endless regret for their disbelief in the Prophet's message. Regret that is meaningless and useless because they have wasted the opportunity and the years that have passed, while the Lord is not unaware of what they do.
